title: Error Handling With Try...Catch
subject: JavaScript
theory:
The `try` statement lets you test a block of code for errors.
The `catch` statement lets you handle the error.
The `throw` statement lets you create custom errors.
The `finally` statement lets you execute code, after try and catch, regardless of the result.

examples.explanation: Throw stops execution and goes to nearest catch.

common_mistakes.correction: Never ignore errors. At least log them.

interview_questions.question: Can I use 'finally' without 'catch'?
interview_questions.answer: Yes. `try { ... } finally { ... }` is valid, but unhandled errors will still crash the script.

real_world_use_cases.description: Always wrap async/await fetch calls in try/catch to handle network failures.

exam_notes: Throwing a string is possible but throwing an Error object is best practice.
summary: Robust applications anticipate and handle errors gracefully.
